--- Kenneth Stanley <kstanley@...> wrote:
> The connections gene representation seems to be
> missing two features
> that I would expect it to have:
> 
>    -An enable/disable bit

Yes, you're right about this.  Currently we haven't
implemented this aspect of NEAT, but any XML standard
we agree on should have some sort of boolean enabled
attribute (e.g., "<connection id="10"
enabled="true"...>")

>    -A recurrency flag

To clarify a bit...we've got both "Chromosome XML" and
"Network XML" in our implementation.  The chromosome
XML is used for handling all the GA logic, which only
needs to know which individuals are in the same
species, who mates with whom, etc.  The genetic
material, in other words, doesn't need to know how the
phenotype functions.  We have a transcriber object
that takes chromosome XML and translates it into
network XML, from which a working phenotype can then
be constructed.  So network XML does contain boolean
recurrency attributes for connections.

> In particular, I am not sure how the NEAT algorithm
> can be 
> implemented (with respect to the standard operations
> in our papers)
> without the ability to disable a gene?  

It seems to work reasonably well without that
functionality implemented.  As we incrementally added
features into our implementation, the one that seemed
to have the most impact was elitism.  

> Also the
> previous discussion
> on simplification would require such a tag.

You could simply delete genes, but I agree that
disabling them, with a chance for later reactivation
is the most biologically plausible approach, and
probably the best.
 
> One other thing about printing out entire
> populations.  In my
> population files (which C++ NEAT users may have
> noticed are usually
> called gen_#) I concatenate the whole population of
> genomes into
> a single file, wherein the genomes are clustered by
> species, and
> there is a comment line before each species and
> before each individual
> giving stats.  

Well, again, XML is fairly easy to parse using XSL
into pretty much any text-based layout.  Just in
general, it's a lot easier to manipulate and reformat
information, and create the types of summaries you
listed, and the nice thing about it is that it's all
implementation-neutral.

If we can agree on a decent XML standard, we can all
use each other's XSL style sheets to sort and group
information from runs.

> Anyway, just some ideas to keep in mind.  I've found
> it very 
> convenient to to be able to do these things with my
> output
> files, although I realize there are a million ways
> you can
> visualize, edit, summarize, etc. population files.

Right...and XML should be a good,
implementation-neutral standard.

Derek
